DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China's Commerce Ministry is to encourage companies to increase imports of soybean, soymeal, vehicles and aquatic products from other markets, while it added it is continually monitoring effect of US trade action on companies. (Newswires)

China reportedly asked the country’s media to soften criticism of US President Trump. (SCMP)
 

UK

UK announced Dominic Raab as the new Brexit Secretary who will be leaving his position as Minister of State for Housing and Planning. Furthermore, Boris Johnson resigned from Foreign Secretary position and Jeremy Hunt was named as his replacement, while Geoffrey Cox was named as the new Attorney-General and Chief Legal Officer. (Newswires)

There were some initial rumours that suggested pro-Brexit lawmakers have the necessary 48 'letters' to force a confidence vote on UK PM May. However, this was followed by comments from UK Conservative Party chairman Lewis that he doesn’t expect a confidence vote against PM May, while Eurosceptic lawmaker Rees-Mogg also doesn’t expect a confidence vote. (Newswires)

UK PM May said Brexit transition period will not be extended and that if the EU continues on the path they are, there is a serious risk of a disorderly no deal Brexit. Elsewhere, there were also comments from a PM May spokesperson that there is no question of revisiting the Brexit position agreed by the Cabinet on Friday. (Newswires)

Germany Deputy Foreign Minister Roth said he would like Brexit talks to be concluded by October and is aiming to reach a good deal. (Newswires)


EU

German Chancellor Merkel said the EU must seek a resolution on trade with the US and that they are seeking an agreement, while she added that multilateralism offers a win-win on trade. (Newswires)

ECB's Nowotny (Hawkish) said trade war risks are less dramatic than at first sight and that in addition to a trade war, there could be a currency war that could have a more serious effect, while he added that ECB has achieved goals to a large extent. (Newswires)

FX

TRY weakened as President Erdogan announced his new cabinet in which he appointed his son-in-law Berat Albayrak as Treasury and Finance Minister which replaces roles held by Deputy PM Simsek and Finance Minister Agbal who were both viewed as market friendly and were also seen as key advocates for higher rates. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

UAE Energy Minister Al-Mazrouei said time is needed for extra supply to come into the market and that OPEC has enough capacity to offset output shortfalls, while he added that OPEC doesn't want to overdo efforts to boost supply. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Friday’s ‘Goldilocks’ jobs report in the US is being cited for the firm tone in risk assets at the beginning of the week (decent payroll growth, while earnings growth does not necessitate more aggressive FOMC tightening), with traders putting concerns of trade wars on the back burner. Analysts noted that markets have absorbed the first trade actions by the US (and China’s retaliation) with calm, perhaps because the news had been discounted meaning that there was no real surprise, or perhaps because economic indicators have not suggested any fallout from trade wars, which some believe will give Trump further ammunition to take a bellicose approach. The constructive risk backdrop helped Asia stocks to follow their US counterparts in rallying on Monday, and the ES maintained its gradual, upward path, though hit resistance around 2785. In stock specific news, US President Trump tweeted Pfizer (PFE) and others should be ashamed that they have raised drug prices, and warned "we will respond" seeing drug names (MRK, BMY, ESRX, TEVA) take a hit in afternoon trade, though losses were pared. Social media company Twitter (TWTR) was slammed after news that it suspended 70mln fake accounts but pared some of those losses when its CFO said those users were not included in Twitter’s reported metrics. Groupon (GRPN) was boosted after RECODE reported that the company is seeking to sell itself. Boeing (BA) outperformed on reports the Saudi state airline is mulling an order of 777X widebody jets, potentially offsetting some of the 80 jets IranAir ordered, but likely won’t be completed due to US re-imposing sanctions on Iran. Banking stocks were up ahead of the beginning of earnings season this week (JPM, C, WFC report Friday). An apparent cooling of trade war tensions also helped industrials CAT, LMT, NOC as well as BA. Snap Inc (SNAP) bounced on reports it has developed a visual product search feature that delivers users to Amazon (AMZN) listings. Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) gained on news that Comcast (CMCSA) is seeking to line-up buyers for Fox’s regional sports networks. Meanwhile, Comcast (CMCSA) is expected to make a formal $31bln bid for Sky (SKY LN) this week, according to Deadline Hollywood. News comes amid reports that the UK government is near approving 21st Century Fox’s (FOXA) bid to purchase 61% of Sky it does not own. Defensive stocks underperformed, with the Utilities sector off by over 3%; telecoms also lagged. SPX +0.9% at 2784, NDX +0.9% at 7276, DJIA +1.3% at 24777.

Treasury yields rose across the curve ahead of this week’s supply, with traders citing an easing of concerns regarding trade wars, as well as a ‘Goldilocks’ labour market report on Friday; rallying stock futures and a slightly higher yuan also were contributing. The long-end led the sell-off, with 10yr yields rising by c.3bps (seeing 2s10s rise a touch, taking it to just under 30bps), resulting in a modestly steeper curve. US 10YR T-notes futures (u8) settled 7 ticks lower at 120-04.

US MARKET WRAP 9 July 2018: Trade wars fears put on the back-burner; UK Foreign Minister follows Brexit Secretary in quitting Cabinet
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, dollar up, crude mixed.  
* REAR-VIEW: Eurosceptics Davis and Johnson quit UK Cabinet; risk markets firm as trade war concerns put on back burner.
* COMING-UP: US JOLTS; API inventories; PepsiCo earnings; US 3yr note auction; UK industrial and manufacturing production.

* BREXIT: Boris Johnson resigned as UK Foreign Secretary, following the resignation of Brexit Secretary David Davis with both unhappy about the Brexit negotiating position UK PM May has agreed with her Cabinet. The former has been replaced by the pro-Brexit Dominic Raab, and Jeremy Hunt was named new Foreign Minister. Pricing of a BOE rate hike probability for August has fallen by around 6ppts in the day to around 60%, and bookies have narrowed the odds on May leaving her post as PM (one bookie quotes 2/1 on May to go this week, and quotes 5/6 to be gone in the next quarter; odds of a 2018 General Election has been cut to 6/4 from 5/1). Various media reports, however, suggest that the confidence motion is unlikely to hit on Monday; later, Conservative Party chairman said he does not expect a confidence vote against May. Ahead of Thursday's release of the long-awaited White Paper, which will outline the relationship the UK desires with the EU post-Brexit, UK PM May met with MPs on Monday in an attempt to rally them behind her position ahead of the debate in Parliament next Monday and Tuesday. The government has a majority of 10 in the Lower House, and it is becoming increasingly likely that she may face defeat on her negotiating position as a result of a Eurosceptic rebellion, which would raise the chances of a leadership challenge (48 Conservative MPs are needed to trigger a confidence vote, 159 out of the 316 Conservative MPs are needed to remove her from office). A spokesperson for the Prime Minister said she would fight any attempt to unseat her. However, fears that May could call a fresh General Election, which could result in a Labour Government, may keep the Tory rebels in check, some analysts said. In terms of the negotiating position itself, while May has achieved a 'victory' in her Cabinet, it remains to be seen whether the EU will be amenable to the UK's 'third way' position, with weekend commentary in some parts of Europe suggesting that the proposals are "unacceptable" or "impossible".

* ECB: ECB's Draghi repeats rates to remain at their present levels at least through the summer of 2019, and in any case for as long as necessary to ensure price goals are met. On trade, Draghi says EU can lend support to multilateralism and global trade, which have been cornerstones of growing economic prosperity over the past seven decades; says the threat of increased protectionism is more prominent. On the economy, Draghi says risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook remain broadly balanced, and underlying inflation is expected to pick up. ECB's Coeure said the ECB's June decision already accounts for the risks of trade wars. Coeure said that trade wars could have negative implications for the European economy, though at present, it is not strong enough to derail the recovery, and accordingly, there is no need to adjust the ECB's policy path. ECB’s Nowotny said trade wars were not as dramatic than appeared on first sight, but noted there are still risks of an unintentional currency way, which could have a more serious impact. On policy, Nowotny generally reiterated the ECB’s line.

* SPX +0.9% at 2784, NDX +0.9% at 7276, DJI +1.3% at 24777. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +1.2%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.5%, Energy: +1.5%, Financials: +2.3%, Health Care: +0.7%, Industrials: +1.8%, Materials: +0.9%, Telecoms: -1.4%, Tech: +0.8%, Utilities: -3.1%.

* FUTURES: Friday’s ‘Goldilocks’ jobs report in the US is being cited for the firm tone in risk assets at the beginning of the week (decent payroll growth, while earnings growth does not necessitate more aggressive FOMC tightening), with traders putting concerns of trade wars on the back burner. Analysts noted that markets have absorbed the first trade actions by the US (and China’s retaliation) with calm, perhaps because the news had been discounted meaning that there was no real surprise, or perhaps because economic indicators have not suggested any fallout from trade wars, which some believe will give Trump further ammunition to take a bellicose approach. The constructive risk backdrop helped Asia stocks to follow their US counterparts in rallying on Monday, and the ES maintained its gradual, upward path, though hit resistance around 2785.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: US President Trump tweeted Pfizer (PFE) and others should be ashamed that they have raised drug prices, and warned "we will respond" seeing drug names (MRK, BMY, ESRX, TEVA) take a hit in afternoon trade, though losses were pared. Social media company Twitter (TWTR) was slammed after news that it suspended 70mln fake accounts, but pared some of those losses when its CFO said those users were not included in Twitter’s reported metrics. Groupon (GRPN) was boosted after RECODE reported that the company is seeking to sell itself. Boeing (BA) outperformed on reports the Saudi state airline is mulling an order of 777X widebody jets, potentially offsetting some of the 80 jets IranAir ordered, but likely won’t be completed due to US re-imposing sanctions on Iran. Banking stocks were up ahead of the beginning of earnings season this week (JPM, C, WFC report Friday). An apparent cooling of trade war tensions helped industrials CAT, LMT, NOC as well as BA. Snap Inc (SNAP) bounced on reports it has developed a visual product search feature that delivers users to Amazon (AMZN) listings. Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) gained on news that Comcast (CMCSA) is seeking to line-up buyers for Fox’s regional sports networks. Meanwhile, Comcast (CMCSA) is expected to make a formal $31bln bid for Sky (SKY LN) this week, according to Deadline Hollywood. News comes amid reports that the UK government is near approving 21st Century Fox’s (FOXA) bid to purchase 61% of Sky it does not own. Defensive stocks underperformed, with the Utilities sector off by over 3%; telecoms also lagged.

* BROKER MOVES: Netflix (NFLX) and Capital One Financial (COF) were lifted after positive broker comments; Apple (AAPL) saw a new Street-high price target at Elazar Advisors. Gaming names (WYNN, MGM, LVS) traded higher after Jefferies expects gaming stocks to have a strong July.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLES 7 TICKS LOWER AT 120-04. Treasury yields rose across the curve ahead of this week’s supply, with traders citing an easing of concerns regarding trade wars, as well as a ‘Goldilocks’ labour market report on Friday; rallying stock futures and a slightly higher yuan also were contributing. The long-end led the sell-off, with 10yr yields rising by c.3bps (seeing 2s10s rise a touch, taking it to just under 30bps), resulting in a modestly steeper curve.

* THIS WEEK’S TREASURY AUCTIONS: The Treasury will this week auction USD 69bln in new supply (USD 33bln of 3-year notes on Tuesday, USD 22bln 10-year reopening on Wednesday, USD 14bln of reopened 30-year bonds on Thursday. The auctions will raise USD 28.7bln in new cash given the USD 40.3bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, according to TD Securities. The last three 3-year note auctions have all seen tails of 0.1bps. TD Securities observes that “the gradual increase in dealer takedowns alongside the increase in dealer inventories hints at growing pressure on front-end rates,” and accordingly, it expects 2-year and 3-year Treasuries to continue cheapening against OIS.

* WTI (Q8) SETTLES $0.05 HIGHER AT $73.85/BBL; BRENT (U8) SETTLES $0.96 HIGHER AT $78.07/BBL. Another session of varying performance for the two major global crude benchmarks. Brent was buoyed by continuing tensions in Libya, where oil output has nearly halved since February to 527k BPD, according to the latest reports. Brent also continues to be supported by geopolitics relating to Iran, which has upped its belligerent rhetoric in recent days amid US calls for buyers to seek to buy crude form other sources (Kuwait on Monday hinted Asian buyers were looking to diversify away from Iran). WTI, meanwhile, has been pressured by news that SynCrude Canada will be restarting production from Fort Murray for the first time since 20 June, earlier than expected; but production is only expected to normalise in September. Accordingly, the arbitrage between Brent and WTI weakened, with the August/September WTI spread narrowing. ”While there is certainly a bullish undercurrent of sentiment here, with the Iranian supply question eventually expected to support a further rally, today’s trade entails more rotation between the markets, with traders endeavoring to buy what’s hot and sell what’s not in search of the strongest gains,” Citi’s analysts said.

* GBP: Sterling was higher in early trading on news David Davis quit as Brexit Secretary, with the pound gaining on a ‘softer Brexit’ theme. However, that wasn’t the case when Boris Johnson quit as Foreign Secretary, which saw GBP breach 1.32 to the downside on fears that it could eventually lead to a challenge of UK PM May’s leadership, which in turn may lead to a more hard line Brexiteer, or even a fresh General Election. However, these losses were pared back in evening trade after pro-Brexit lawmaker Rees-Mogg said PM May was not likely to face a confidence vote.

* USD: The Dollar Index was trading on the back foot on a more constructive risk environment, as trade war feats eased. However, the slide in GBP was said to buoy the index, which trades above the 94.00 handle again, having fallen to 93.71 as traders reasoned the ‘Goldilocks’ payrolls report on Friday was unlikely to push the Fed into a more aggressive course of tightening since job growth is still occurring while wage growth remains elusive, potentially signalling more slack in the US labour market.

* MXN: The peso slipped against the USD after June CPI data showed CPI coming in slightly ahead of expectations, with energy pushing prices higher at the end of Q2, though analysts at Pantheon said that inflation is coming under control. Later, Banxico Deputy Governor Guzman said that amid high uncertainty and risks, erring on the side of caution will usually be preferable; economy has not yet been affected by the Banxico's policy stance; on inflation, Guzman said the Banxico’s efforts in reining price pressures was encouraging.

* TRY: The lira sank against the dollar, with USDTRY spiking to 4.6875 as President Erdogan announced his son-in-law would take the role of Treasury and Finance minister, with no room in his cabinet for the market friendly former Deputy PM Mehmet Simsek. The Lira was trading at around 4.6020 prior to Erdogan’s announcements.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Aud eyeing 0.7500 and Eur 1.1800 vs soft Usd
content:
DXY

The index has drifted a bit further below 94.000 towards 93.700, partly amidst more reflection on Friday’s sub-forecast US average earnings and unexpected upturn in the jobless rate, but also as several of the Dollar’s major rivals rallied independently. In terms of technical levels, there is little in the way of support or resistance for the DXY, but 93.500 is an obvious downside level to watch from a psychological perspective.

AUD/GBP/EUR      

All winners vs the flagging Greenback for various reasons and to different degrees, with the Aud inching closer to 0.7500 after breaking resistance between 0.7440-50, but faced with a couple of chart hurdles in advance of the big figure (fib at 0.7494 and 50 DMA at 0.7498). A short squeeze has been the main driver for the Aud, which has also seen the NZD cross back over 1.0900 as the Kiwi struggles to clear 0.6850 vs the Usd. Cable has (finally) lost grip of the 1.3300 handle again amidst yet more UK Government instability on Brexit divisions, with David Davis resigning in protest at PM May’s ‘soft’ White Paper and Foreign Minister Boris Johnson following suit. Gbp did climb above 1.3350 earlier and recover from a sub-1.3300 retreat, but the volatile moves also set against broad Greenback fluctuations, and UK PM May is expected to make a statement soon (15.30BST touted). Elsewhere, Eur/Usd is now drifting back having got to within 10 pips of 1.1800, with little independent impetus coming from either ECB President Draghi or renowned hawk Novotny as they both largely stuck to June policy meeting guidance (for QE to end after December 2018 and rates to go up after Summer next year at the earliest).

TRY/PLN

Lots of focus on the Lira ahead of President Erdogan’s official swearing in ceremony, with EM investors initially lifting the Try close to 4.5100 vs the Usd on hopes that he would retain market friendly personnel in key Government positions, but then the currency sold sharply on changes to CBRT laws by decree that effectively give him more control over the appointments of Deputy Governors. Usd/Try now back up near 4.6000. Conversely, the Zloty is a marked outperformer vs the Eur (over 4.3150 at one stage) after last week’s firm inflation data altered dovish perceptions regarding the NBP policy outlook.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 9th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • UK agrees on white paper proposal with Dominic Raab announced as new UK Brexit Secretary; David Davis resigns
  • European Equities in the green but FTSE underperforms on a stronger GBP
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, ECB’s Praet, Draghi and Fed’s Kashkari

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week higher across the board as the region followed suit to Wall St’s performance on Friday after a Goldilocks US jobs report. The broad appetite for risk saw all majors gains from the open with the ASX 200 (+0.2%) led higher by mining stocks including BHP amid reports BP is front running the bidding for its US shale assets and with Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) supported by a predominantly weaker currency. Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.5%) conformed to the upside with broad gains across the sectors in both indices and which followed the PBoC snapping its recent streak of liquidity drains, while focus in Hong Kong also turned to Xiaomi which declined over 4% in early trade on its debut due to valuation concerns. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as focus was centred around stocks and amid a lack of Rinban announcement, although downside was also stemmed as prices sat near their best levels since May and at close proximity to retest resistance around 151.00.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6393 (Prev. 6.6336)

China's Cabinet has issued a statement on expanding agricultural and resource related imports, promoting trade balance. (Xinhua)

EU/UK/US

UK government outlined its Brexit negotiating position in which it commits UK to ongoing harmonisation with EU on goods that are needed for frictionless trade and stated it wants to work with EU on introduction of a facilitated customs arrangement which would remove need for all border checks between UK and EU as if a combined customs territory. The government added it will seek a different position for services which means the UK will not have current levels of access to the EU and stated that its Brexit negotiating position would end free movement of labour and return control of immigration. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Davis resigned, while he stated that PM May’s policy is now more likely to break the manifesto pledge and leaves the UK in a weak negotiating position. Furthermore, Brexit Minister Steve Baker also resigned, while UK PM May's office named Dominic Raab as the new Brexit Secretary. (Newswires) UK PM May is said to have promised to fire UK Foreign Minister Johnson if he undermines the new Brexit negotiating position, according to reports on Friday. (The Times)

UK Environment Minister Gove said the Brexit plan is a realistic compromise, while he also commented the UK will not walk away from the negotiations now but should be willing to if a "proper" withdrawal from the EU cannot be reached. (Newswires/BBC)

Jacob Rees-Mogg is to vote against UK PM May's Brexit plan, while there were also reports that Brexiteer MPs threaten to topple PM May and replace her with Jacob Rees-Mogg in anger at the PM’s Chequers deal. Furthermore, Jacob Rees-Mogg more recently commented that UK PM May's Brexit plan must be bad if Davis cannot support it and that a serious mistake by PM May led to Davis quitting. (Telegraph/Sun)

EU countries were said to be lobbying EU Brexit negotiator Barnier not to reject the UK White Paper. (Newswires)

British Chambers of Commerce said UK manufacturing and services companies’ domestic sales picked up slightly during Q2 but UK business investment plans and confidence weakened, while it added BoE rhetoric around hiking rates seems ill-judged. (Newswires)

ECB's Coeure said the ECB is not complacent to trade-war risks and that its June decision considered trade and other risks, while he added that Euro zone economy remains strong and that rate guidance has been effective. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are higher (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%), with the FTSE (+0.1%) underperforming due to a higher GBP, as investors monitor developments in the UK following the resignation of UK Brexit Secretary David Davis. The current outperformer is the AEX (+0.8%), which is being lifted by a broker upgrade for index heavyweight Altice (+3.3%) at RBC as well as Orange being open to a potential alliance within their home market.

Air France (+4.0%) reported improved passenger numbers for June vs. May, easing investors’ concerns about strike action that has been hitting the company.

Renault (-2.3%) are currently struggling on the back of emission measurement concerns at their partner co. Nissan.

FIXED INCOME

It’s been quite measured rather than sudden or on anything specific, but nevertheless Bunds and Gilts have fallen further, with the latter now underperforming having lost grip of the 123.00 handle and almost ½ point underwater at 122.79 vs last Friday’s 123.28 close. Its German equivalent just slipped to 162.41 for a 41 tick loss on the day and perhaps a much stronger than expected Sentix index provided some incentive for sellers, but the survey is not usually a major impactor. However, now that the previous session low has been breached 162.30 is near term support ahead of a channel base at 162.19 and then last week’s base at 162.06. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are ticking lower in sympathy and the curve is mildly steeper.

FX

AUD

The top G10 performer on a mixture of better risk sentiment overall, short covering and stops on a break of technical resistance, with Aud/Usd up through 0.7440-50 to just over 0.7475 and bulls now eyeing a Fib level just shy of 0.7500.

GBP

Cable has recovered well from a wobble and brief retreat through 1.3300 in wake of David Davis’ resignation due to what he perceives to be a too soft EU withdrawal White Paper from the UK Government, with market contacts noting stops on a break of 1.3330 on the way to a 1.3360 high, and also noting stops vs the EUR at 0.8800 in the cross that is currently towards the bottom of a 0.8850-15 range. However, the single currency is fairing much better vs a generally soft USD following the weaker than forecast elements of last Friday’s US jobs report, with a Fib breached around 1.1720 and peak around 1.1780, opening up scope to 1.1800, while the DXY has extended losses to just below 93.800.

CHF

The Franc is also benefiting on the back of the Greenback’s demise, to trade near 0.9850, and with little reaction to somewhat mixed Swiss unemployment data.

NZD/CAD/JPY

All pretty flat, with the Kiwi capped around 0.6850 and somewhat outflanked by its antipodean neighbour as the Aud/Nzd cross rebounds above 1.0900. The Loonie is holding in a relatively tight 1.3100-1.3070 range vs its US rival, while Usd/Jpy continues to pivot 110.50.

TRY

The Lira is firmer and back over 4.5500 vs. Usd as traders await an announcement at 18.00 from the Erdogan Government on their cabinet line-up

COMMODITIES

Oil is currently mixed and WTI/Brent spreads widening, with Brent +0.75% and WTI -0.25%. WTI has broken through the USD 74/BBL & 200 DMA levels to the downside, with investors eyeing the 50 and 100DMA levels as key supports at USD 73.52/BBL and USD 73.49 respectively in the wake of increased supply form the US, as Baker Hughes noted an increased rig count for the first time in several weeks.

Gold prices are up and being lifted to two week highs at USD 1,260/Oz by a softer dollar and short covering. London copper has rebounded from a close to 1 year low in the previous session, and is up 1.8% on the day as a weaker dollar has also forced short covering for the construction material.

BP is in the lead to acquire the U.S. onshore shale oil and gas assets of BHP submitting an offer worth over USD 10bln; according to sources.

Ahead, July’s Sentix Eurozone sentiment gauge, but ECB speeches likely to be more influential in terms of fundamental direction, with Praet and President Draghi both scheduled.

FTSE

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 9th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks began the week higher across the board as the region followed suit to Wall St’s performance on Friday

UK Brexit Secretary Davis resigned, stating that PM May’s policy is now more likely to break the manifesto pledge and leaves the UK in a weak negotiating position

Looking ahead, highlights include German trade, ECB’s Praet, Draghi and Fed’s Kashkari

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week higher across the board as the region followed suit to Wall St’s performance on Friday after a Goldilocks US jobs report. The broad appetite for risk saw all majors gains from the open with the ASX 200 (+0.2%) led higher by mining stocks including BHP amid reports BP is front running the bidding for its US shale assets and with Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) supported by a predominantly weaker currency. Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.7%) conformed to the upside with broad gains across the sectors in both indices and which followed the PBoC snapping its recent streak of liquidity drains, while focus in Hong Kong also turned to Xiaomi which declined over 4% in early trade on its debut due to valuation concerns. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued as focus was centred around stocks and amid a lack of Rinban announcement, although downside was also stemmed as prices sat near their best levels since May and at close proximity to retest resistance around 151.00.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6393 (Prev. 6.6336)


UK

UK government outlined its Brexit negotiating position in which it commits UK to ongoing harmonisation with EU on goods that are needed for frictionless trade and stated it wants to work with EU on introduction of a facilitated customs arrangement which would remove need for all border checks between UK and EU as if a combined customs territory. The government added it will seek a different position for services which means the UK will not have current levels of access to the EU and stated that its Brexit negotiating position would end free movement of labour and return control of immigration. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Davis resigned, while he stated that PM May’s policy is now more likely to break the manifesto pledge and leaves the UK in a weak negotiating position. Furthermore, Brexit Ministers Steve Baker and Suella Braverman have also resigned, while UK PM May's office said they will name Brexit Secretary today. (Newswires) UK PM May is said to have promised to fire UK Foreign Minister Johnson if he undermines the new Brexit negotiating position, according to reports on Friday. (The Times)

UK Environment Minister Gove said the Brexit plan is a realistic compromise, while he also commented the UK will not walk away from the negotiations now but should be willing to if a "proper" withdrawal from the EU cannot be reached. (Newswires/BBC)

Jacob Rees-Mogg is to vote against UK PM May's Brexit plan, while there were also reports that Brexiteer MPs threaten to topple PM May and replace her with Jacob Rees-Mogg in anger at the PM’s Chequers deal. Furthermore, Jacob Rees-Mogg more recently commented that UK PM May's Brexit plan must be bad if Davis cannot support it and that a serious mistake by PM May led to Davis quitting. (Telegraph/Sun)

EU countries were said to be lobbying EU Brexit negotiator Barnier not to reject the UK White Paper. (Newswires)

British Chambers of Commerce said UK manufacturing and services companies’ domestic sales picked up slightly during Q2 but UK business investment plans and confidence weakened, while it added BoE rhetoric around hiking rates seems ill-judged. (Newswires)


EU

ECB's Coeure said the ECB is not complacent to trade-war risks and that its June decision considered trade and other risks, while he added that Euro zone economy remains strong and that rate guidance has been effective. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained subdued and below the 94.00 level in the wake of the mixed US jobs data. This saw the greenback’s major counterparts extend their gains with EUR/USD near its highest level in over 3 weeks, while GBP/USD was also firmer on PM May’s soft Brexit proposal despite a bout of pressure on the resignation of Brexit Secretary Davis and Brexit Ministers Baker and Braverman. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies gained amid strength in oil and metals prices, which also coincided with a firmer CNH following a larger than expected increase in Chinese Foreign Reserves.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were higher across the board in which WTI crude futures reclaimed the USD 74/bbl to the upside in an extension of Friday’s advances and amid broad upside across commodities, while there were also reports of Saudi Aramco’s chief was concerned regarding a supply crunch amid increasing demand. Elsewhere, gold was underpinned by a softer greenback following the US jobs data, while copper outperformed on the risk appetite and in tandem with an early surge in Shanghai metal prices.

Saudi Aramco CEO Nasser is reportedly concerned on oil supply crunch and sees projects such as shale insufficient in meeting increasing demand. (FT)
 

US Baker Hughes Rig Count (6 July): Total rigs +5 to 1052 (Prev. 1047). (Newswires)


Oil prices could hit USD 100/bbl if Iranian supply is cut, according to reports. (SHANA)


GEOPOLITICAL

North Korean Foreign Ministry stated discussions with US Secretary of State Pompeo were 'regrettable' and accused the US of unilateral demands for denuclearization. (Newswires)

Syria stated that Israel launched a strike on a T-4 military base in Homs, Syria. (SANA)

US

Treasuries drifted mildly higher and the yield curve continued to flatten, though the complex gave up most of the gains seen after the solid NFP report and as equities continued to climb higher. Yields across the curve were higher by c.1bps. 10s30 narrowed by c.1bps whilst all the other spread widened by less than 1bps. US 10YR T-notes futures (u8) settles 3 ticks higher at 120-11.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain in reaction to Goldilocks US jobs data; GBP in focus and remains firm on PM May's soft Brexit plans despite early wobble on Brexit Secretary and Ministers resignations
content:
Asia stocks begin the week higher across the board as region follows suit to Wall St’s performance on Friday following a Goldilocks US jobs report in which Non-Farm Payrolls topped estimates, while Average Earnings was softer than expected and Unemployment Rate surprisingly increased to 4.0% which places doubts on the Fed’s Unemployment projections for a decline to 3.6% for the current year. The broad appetite for risk saw all majors gains from the open with the ASX 200 (+0.2%) led higher by mining stocks including BHP amid reports BP is front running the bidding for its US shale assets and with Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) supported by a predominantly weaker currency. Hang Seng (+1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.5%) conform to the upside with broad gains across the sectors in both indices and which follows the PBoC snapping its recent streak of liquidity drains, while focus in Hong Kong also turned to Xiaomi which declined over 4% in early trade on its debut due to valuation concerns.

In FX markets, the DXY remains subdued and below the 94.00 level in the wake of the mixed US jobs data in which a higher Unemployment Rate and softer wage growth casted doubts on Fed forecasts and slightly dampened expectations for 4 hikes this year. This saw the greenback’s major counterparts extend their gains with EUR/USD testing its highest level in over 3 weeks, while GBP/USD is also firmer on PM May’s soft Brexit proposal despite a bout of pressure on the resignation of Brexit Secretary Davis and Brexit Ministers Baker and Braverman. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies have gained amid strength in oil and metals prices, which also coincides with a firmer CNH following a larger than expected increase in Chinese Foreign Reserves.

Finally, 10yr JGBs was subdued as focus was centred around stocks and amid a lack of Rinban announcement, although downside was also stemmed with prices remaining near its best levels since May and at close proximity to retest the 151.00 level.
